moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 g6 6. Be3 Bg7 7. f3 Nc6 8. Qd2
comment:
Up to here, I'd been following Karpov-Korchnoi 1974. Douglas now surprises me
with his reply - I'd expected 0-0 or Bd7.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 g6 6. Be3 Bg7 7. f3 Nc6 8. Qd2 h5 9. Nxc6 bxc6 10. Bc4 Qc7 11. O-O
comment:
With Douglas seemingly intent on not castling, I thought I'd be a touch
perverse and invite a further K-side advance.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 g6 6. Be3 Bg7 7. f3 Nc6 8. Qd2 h5 9. Nxc6 bxc6 10. Bc4 Qc7 11. O-O h4 12. h3 Bd7 13. Rad1 Nh5 14. Bd4
comment:
Trying to be consistent with one of the original objectives of the
opening - removal of the fianchettoed Bishop.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 g6 6. Be3 Bg7 7. f3 Nc6 8. Qd2 h5 9. Nxc6 bxc6 10. Bc4 Qc7 11. O-O h4 12. h3 Bd7 13. Rad1 Nh5 14. Bd4 Bxd4+ 15. Qxd4 Rf8 16. Ne2 Rd8 17. Kh1
comment: To keep the Queens on.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 g6 6. Be3 Bg7 7. f3 Nc6 8. Qd2 h5 9. Nxc6 bxc6 10. Bc4 Qc7 11. O-O h4 12. h3 Bd7 13. Rad1 Nh5 14. Bd4 Bxd4+ 15. Qxd4 Rf8 16. Ne2 Rd8 17. Kh1 Nf6
comment: Here I felt White had the better position.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 g6 6. Be3 Bg7 7. f3 Nc6 8. Qd2 h5 9. Nxc6 bxc6 10. Bc4 Qc7 11. O-O h4 12. h3 Bd7 13. Rad1 Nh5 14. Bd4 Bxd4+ 15. Qxd4 Rf8 16. Ne2 Rd8 17. Kh1 Nf6 18. e5 dxe5 19. Qxh4 Bf5 20. c3 Nd5 21. Ng3 Ne3 22. Rxd8+ Qxd8 23. Re1 Qd2
comment: But now Black recovers lost ground with some energetic play.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 g6 6. Be3 Bg7 7. f3 Nc6 8. Qd2 h5 9. Nxc6 bxc6 10. Bc4 Qc7 11. O-O h4 12. h3 Bd7 13. Rad1 Nh5 14. Bd4 Bxd4+ 15. Qxd4 Rf8 16. Ne2 Rd8 17. comment:
Reactivating White's Queen and
stirring up some tactical play was more important than the b2 pawn.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 g6 6. Be3 Bg7 7. f3 Nc6 8. Qd2 h5 9. Nxc6 bxc6 10. Bc4 Qc7 11. O-O h4 12. h3 Bd7 13. Rad1 Nh5 14. Bd4 Bxd4+ 15. Qxd4 Rf8 16. Ne2 Rd8 17. comment:
#This seems a natural response to break the pin, but it is probably the
losing move. The Knight is now dangerously marginalised. Nd1 looks better.

The White King has survived his
cross-country trek, and although Bishop for 3 pawns looks equal, White's
superior mobiity gives the edge.
